content: @Yoh Tanimoto just FYI, I think @Jon Bannon already has everything for the algebraic structure on L^infty.

Jireh Loreaux said:

Yoh Tanimoto just FYI, I think Jon Bannon already has everything for the algebraic structure on L^infty.

ah! are these getting PR'ed?

@Yoh Tanimoto : What Jireh and I have so far is the CStarAlgebra instance for L^infty. I do intend to PR it, but I'm still operating pretty slowly here. I should hopefully get to the PR for this soon.
Wow...you guys are inspiring me to get down to this!
where (on which branch/fork/project) is that definition?

It's here :
https://github.com/j-loreaux/LeanOA/tree/BFC/LeanOA/ForMathlib/Analysis/WStarAlgebra/BorelFunctionalCalculus

This is Jireh's repo for developing OA. I imagine you are already working on stuff in here, Yoh?

By the way, the support stuff in that file is obsolete. We now have a much better filter-based definition and are proving a bunch of API for that. I was going to PR those results, then stuff about the essential range, and then the CStarAlgebra instance...but I'm unfortunately still a greenhorn at this and move very slowly!

well, I've just started, so it's good to know that you already have much stuff!

I wanted L^\infty because Rudin uses it to prove the spectral theorem

Oliver Butterley said:

That's wonderful, thank you. filter_upwards is magical! Although a magic I struggle to understand or use.

@Oliver Butterley : You aren't kidding. It's a really fantastic tactic. There are a bunch of use cases in the file I just shared above with Yoh.
Yoh and I are here together looking through your file. It's great, thanks for sharing. We thought we would have to recreate much of it from nothing so happy we can focus on the other stuff.
So glad to know I've been helpful!
@Jon Bannon why don't you make that into an actual PR to LeanOA (or Mathlib) and I'll try to review it within the next week?
Sure. It seems like it's farther along than the support stuff, right?
You could do both.

Jovan Gerbscheid said:

Did you mean docs#Filter.Eventually.mp?

Yeah, it's kind-of both. filter_upwards with n+1 arguments can be done manually by using n times docs#Filter.Eventually.mp and 1 time docs#Eventually.mono (or n+1 times docs#Filter.Eventually.mp and 1 time docs#Filter.Eventually.of_forall)

Yoh Tanimoto said:

well, I've just started, so it's good to know that you already have much stuff!

I wanted L^\infty because Rudin uses it to prove the spectral theorem

New here, but I was wondering how far away the spectral theorem for bounded operators is?

@Laura Monk We have docs#continuousFunctionalCalculus, but have yet to develop the projection-valued measure machinery and the Borel Functional Calculus (I am aiming at that). After we get those, I hope getting an integral representation won't be too far off. @Jireh Loreaux will have a much more accurate view of what's done.

Together with Yoh we were aiming for the spectral theorem more or less following the approach of Rudin. One ingredient of this will be the Riesz(-Markov-Kakutani) representation theorem for complex-valued linear functionals and this is my current focus. This uses the real-valued case which we already finalized. It also requires total variation for complex measures which is finished (in the sense of a functioning version, possibly not the best version). I'll let @Yoh Tanimoto add some details about the other part.

@Jireh Loreaux, @Jon Bannon, coordinating a bit would be great for efficiency to not duplicate work (and also just the pleasure of doing things together)! Additionally I would really appreciate some guidance from those more knowledgeable with mathlib, I can typically get something done that works but often it not the best design choice.
@Jireh Loreaux Can you move this (very interesting, so worth following) conversation to a more appropriate thread?
I have no computer for several days still, only mobile access, so I can't do it myself. Feel free though.
I don't think I can -- maintainers do, right?
Where should the move start?
Also, a suggested topic name would help me not to think. Hard...

I think here
#mathlib4 > âœ” `rw` with ae relations @ ðŸ’¬
and probably "L^infty as C*-algebra"
24 messages were moved here from #mathlib4 > âœ” `rw` with ae relations by Matthew Ballard.

That is really cool, I will keep a close eye on this! And I am happy to try and join in the effort one day when I become more capable. I work in spectral theory so the spectral theorem is a somehow big prerequisite ahah.

nice to see people interested in the spectral theorem!
I wrote a tentative definition of resolution of identity as in Rudin's "Functional analysis" here, without many details yet, but I sketched the missing steps at the end of the file.
https://github.com/oliver-butterley/SpectralThm/blob/main/SpectralThm/Resolutions.lean

There arose a question how we should define vector-valued measures and their integrals (discussed in #Is there code for X? > fourier transform on locally compact abelian groups ). As Oliver said, there are many options for design choices, including which version of the spectral theorem we would like to have (first) in mathlib, so suggestions are much appreciated.

Personally I prefer the one in Rudin's book, so for this we would need a complex version of the RMK theorem.

@Yoh Tanimoto , @Oliver Butterley : First of all, have you read my paper with Anatole Dedecker about the continuous functional calculus? It's quite relevant to this discussion. I've been talking with @Jon Bannon about the Borel functional calculus (for bounded operators). Of course, we will need some version of the spectral theorem in order to prove it, so it's fantastic to have your work on RMK and vector-valued measures in progress.

Ultimately, I think the design we want for the borel functional calculus is going to parallel docs#ContinuousFunctionalCalculus in many ways, but we'll make a few replacements:

  1. We'll replace C(spectrum R a, R) with Lp R âˆž (volume : Measure (spectrum R a)) (volume descends to subtypes, right?).
  2. We'll need to use a WStarAlgebra[^1] and consider the type synonym where we equip it with the ultraweak topology induced by the predual (i.e., the weakâ‹†-topology relative to the predual).
  3. The star homomorphism won't be a closed embedding from Lâˆž to the algebra, but rather between these when we equip them with the ultraweak topology type synonyms.
  4. We replace the range of a function with its essential range.
  5. Like with docs#cfc, we define a bfc which operates on bare functions.

Note: the functional calculus for unbounded operators will be another beast entirely, I'm afraid. I don't see any way to get around this (especially since normal operators would be left in the lurch), but I'm open to suggestions.

[1] : I'm afraid that there might be a bit of a bootstrapping problem where we need to show that every vonNeumannAlgebra is a WStarAlgebra, and vice versa. We'll need to discuss this.

Of course, the above also indicates that we need to recognize Lâˆž as a WStarAlgebra, which is why Jon was writing the CStarAlgebra instance in the first place. I did some work a few months ago with the HÃ¶lder inequality, which yielded docs#ContinuousLinearMap.lpPairing. It remains to show that in the scalar case, this map is isometric and surjective, which you should be able to make happen with your work on RMK and vector-valued integrals.

Thanks for the link to the paper on the continuous functional calculus, I wasn't aware of it. It's good to have a place to read the details! Thanks also for taking the time to write the overview of the argument here, this is much appreciated.

In terms of smallish details:

  • Whatever the approach is, the as yet not completed RMK for complex-valued linear functionals will be important? If so, should this result be in a particular form?

Many thanks for the detalied explanation! in your paper I see many subtleties which I need to digest...

OK, so with Oliver we are trying to have the spectral theorem. It's great that you have continuous functional calculus and L^\infty as a C^*-algebra. this should be plugged in the complex version of the RMK theorem (to do), extending it to Borel functions and that should give a resolution of identity. given a normal opereator a, this resolution of identity is used to reconstruct a. will this version helpful for you?

sure, unbounded operators are far more difficult, even mathematically. I guess the current status is docs#Mathlib.Analysis.InnerProductSpace.LinearPMap?
@Laura Monk if you're interested in working on this too, just let me know! :smiling_face:

Thanks! I will let you know, but it might not be before a good while as I have just started learning (and I am not super knowledgable in these maths). However this will stand in the way of other things I am very keen on so I might take the opportunity to learn :).

@Laura Monk once you have some idea of the basics, by far the most efficient approach to become a competent Lean user is to just get started on a mathematically interesting project (rather than proving a+b=b+a or whatever) especially if other more experienced users are also involved, and then to post code which solves specific sorries and get other people to review and improve your code.

Are there some concrete sorrys out there for people interested in this project to work on?

Ah! This is yet another good idea I should have thought of. I am sure Jireh has good sorrys...but preliminarily I wouldn't mind coming up with some. In fact, I was talking with Jan Cameron yesterday and he wants to start getting involved and I couldn't think of the best way to involve him. This would be a nice way to do it. Thanks @Kevin Buzzard . I suppose for people really just starting out, sending things for the playground might not even be bad. This might even help people like me who are only slightly further along learn a bit faster, too...
Well, I have had a little think and a little look at Rudin and I am happy to try and help. You'll have to bear with me being slow at first ;).

@Laura Monk : I'm just mentioning this because I think the phenomenon warrants a highlight. Be gentle on yourself about being slow/writing horrendous proofs that can be golfed significantly...or even to be very slow finding proofs of simple things at all. It's just sooo easy to beat yourself up about not catching on to this stuff quickly. Somehow it seems to be the perfect mix of being the most fun possible and also the most likely to make you want to quit...all at the same time. :laughing:

Thank you @Jon Bannon for the great advice :)

@Jireh Loreaux, @Jon Bannon , @Oliver Butterley , @Yoh Tanimoto: Let me know how you want to work / communicate and how I can help, don't hesitate to be quite specific.

I have more thoughts to share here, and I'll rope some other people in (namely FrÃ©dÃ©ric Dupuis and Anatole Dedecker ), but right now I have some things going on personally, so it may be a week or two before I get around to writing them down.
I am going away starting next week so probably will mostly be able to help when I am back in September.

I wrote a tentative statement of the spectral theorem, with a huge amount of sorrys. Most probably I will have to modify some intermediate definitions, using L^infty. Comments are welcome!
https://github.com/oliver-butterley/SpectralThm/blob/main/SpectralThm/SpectralTheorem.lean

@Laura Monk so, that's the current state of the spectral theorem for (normal) bounded operators. Some sorrys are easy, but some others might require a considreable amount of work. Maybe, if you would like to try some of them, will you let us know? I will be busy from September on.

That's great! @Yoh Tanimoto, would it be possible (if it makes sense) to add a brief overview in the docstring of the proof so readers of the file can very easily jump in and understand what the different parts do? Also the precise reference could be useful for those who need more details to understand a particular part.
that's a good point, I will try to add more comments about proofs and references (mainly Rudin "Functional calculus", sometimes "Real and Complex analysis")

Kevin Buzzard said:

by far the most efficient approach to become a competent Lean user is to just get started on a mathematically interesting project (rather than proving a+b=b+a or whatever) especially if other more experienced users are also involved, and then to post code which solves specific sorries and get other people to review and improve your code.

Yes, this is absolutely the best way! I wish I could find more opportunities for myself to contribute where there is an overall structure already laid out.

All this just means that I need to make a blueprint for some work in operator algebras. I had been putting this off because I didn't feel like we had a quorum of interested parties, but it seems as though that's changed.
@Yoh Tanimoto great, I will have a look and let you know!

@Yoh Tanimoto, I realized that some of the argument I wrote in RMK/Complex.lean is a bit of a mess although I have clarity in my mind about this. I'll try to tidy it up tomorrow and separate stuff related to complex integrals into a separate file (unless you do it before then).
added more comments.
